The 3 pedals are from left to right:
Clutch\t\t\t\t\tBrake\t\t\t\t\tGas
When starting the engine, make sure to:
Push down the clutch pedal
To shift gears:

Off the gas
Out of gear
Hit the clutch
Put in gear
Let off clutch while hitting gas
When do you shift down?
To accelerate\nOn hills
When do you shift up?
When the rpm increases to around the 3\nTo coast/maintain current speed
If you need to brake but you are scared it will stall the car, always remember:

Push down the clutch pedal
or
Pull the stick out of gear

You will never stall the car when it is in neutral
When turning off the engine, make sure to:
Park in gear\nUse the emergency break
The right foot controls the gas and brake, just like in an automatic car. The left foot controls the clutch.
If you have trouble getting the car to start this should be the first thing you check. The car will not start if the clutch pedal is not pushed down.
The hardest part of learning to drive stick is getting down the feel of easing into the gas while letting off the clutch.\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
If it\'s not done correctly the car will stall and you will have to restart the engine.\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
The easiest way to practice this is on a downhill slope, using gravity to help propel the car forward.
Higher speeds use higher gears, but downshifting gives you more power to get up to the higher speeds\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
Uphill slopes also need the extra power from downshifting to maintain your speed due to gravity pushing against you
The more you accelerate the higher the rpm goes up, making the engine do more work.\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
You don\'t need as much power to coast or maintain speed, so shifting up will give the engine a break and improve gas mileage.\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
Check your car\'s owner manual for a specified recommended shift point
Stalling is unlikely once the car is already moving, but knowing this trick can calm this common fear.
Stick shifts do not have a designated parking gear so you must use the emergency break.\n(Press DETAILS for more…)
Parking in gear also helps prevent rolling. Depending on the slope use first gear to prevent rolling backward or reverse to prevent rolling forward.
